body: • After defeating Napoleon at the battle of Waterloo, the Duke of Wellington went on to become prime minister in 1828, not 1822 as we had it in an Opinion piece (Forget Hitler, think Wellington, 25 May, page 31). • Two life peers were given the wrong titles in early editions of Monday’s paper. Shirley Williams is a baroness, not a dame (Osborne: vote for Brexit would lead to ‘DIY recession’​, page 6); Michael Heseltine is a baron not a knight (Don’t muzzle immigration debate, minister warns, page 7). • A piece about the singer Adele referred to her “reticence to put herself in the public eye”; reluctance, that should have been. Reticence means an unwillingness to speak (She really has it all: Adele signs Sony deal, 24 May, page 3). • The edition numbers given on the leader page in Friday’s Saturday’s and Monday’s papers were 500 less than they should have been. Friday’s should have been labelled as edition number 52,789, Saturday’s as 52,790, and Monday’s as 52,791.
